title-group.article-title: Plasma Cell Granuloma of the Thyroid Gland
title-group.subtitle: A Challenging Diagnostic Problem

author-notes.corresp: Maurilio Ponzoni, Pathology Unit, San Raffaele Scientific Institute, Via Olgettina 60, 20132 Milan, Italy Email: ponzoni.maurilio@hsr.it

abstract.p: This study reports a case of plasma cell granuloma of the thyroid gland in a 47-year-old woman, presenting with a right subhyoid mass and a previous diagnosis of Hashimoto thyroiditis dating back to 1988, which was made on a subtotal thyroidectomy. Plasma cell granuloma preferentially involves the lung, with only 18 cases of thyroid gland involvement having been reported to date in the English literature. Thyroid plasma cell granuloma preferentially affects women and classically shows a prominent plasma cell infiltrate embedded in a variable degree of fibrous stroma: only 2 of the reported cases exhibited the morphologic features of inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor. These morphologic features may raise problems in the differential diagnosis with other plasma cell–rich disorders, including infectious diseases and auto(dys)immune conditions, including the recently described “IgG4-related sclerosing disease.” In view of these considerations, a contemporary diagnostic approach to thyroid plasma cell granuloma is therefore discussed here.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Plasma cell granuloma (PCG) is a rare form of pseudotumor of unknown origin characterized by a dense polyclonal plasmacytic infiltrate.1 It generally affects the lung, although it has also been reported in many other sites, including the thyroid gland. Thyroid involvement by PCG is a rare occurrence, with only 18 cases having been reported so far in the English literature. PCG displays morphological features such as to generate problems in the differential diagnosis with various neoplastic and nonneoplastic disorders. We present a case of PCG arising in the thyroid gland and discuss its main histopathological differential diagnosis, also in light of recently described new pathological entities. The requirement for a precise diagnosis is relevant, since these lesions may be managed with divergent therapeutic strategies.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: A 47-year-old woman was admitted to our hospital in May 2008 complaining of a right subhyoid mass. In 1988, she had undergone a subtotal thyroidectomy with a clinical diagnosis of Graves’ disease. Histological examination showed adenomatous goitre and Hashimoto thyroiditis. During periodic follow-up, postsurgical hypothyroidism was diagnosed and successfully treated by oral administration of L-thyroxine. The current mass was painless and progressively increasing in diameter. A neck ultrasound examination revealed a hypoechoic, vascularized solid mass with sharp polycyclic margins (46 × 31 × 53 mm). The lesion was placed between the right tracheal border and the cervical vascular axis, extending from the lower margin of the thyroid cartilage to the region of the inferior jugular vein. A computed tomography scan confirmed the ultrasound findings. Ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration of the mass showed a mild number of naked spindle nuclei, suggestive of mesenchymal proliferation. Because of these findings, the patient underwent excision of the lesion. A solid encapsulated mass with sharp margins was resected. The postoperative course was uneventful. Routine laboratory test were normal. The serum levels of IgG4 were normal (1.69 g/L, normal range: 0.03-2.3 g/L).

The surgical specimen measured 5 cm in maximum diameter. It was surrounded by a grayish capsule, with a white yellowish, vaguely nodular, hard elastic cut surface. The entire lesion was submitted for microscopic examination. Formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded specimens were stained with hematoxylin and eosin and Congo Red stain for amyloid. The list of antibodies tested by immunohistochemistry is summarized in Table 1. Specimens were stained for CD3, CD20, CD23, Kappa and Lambda chains, human herpes virus 8 (HHV8), Epstein–Barr virus (EBV), Chlamydia, IgG, and IgG4. In situ hybridization was performed for EBV, and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was carried out for Chlamydia (species pneumoniae, psittaci, and trachomatis). The specimen removed 19 years earlier was tested for IgG and IgG4.

caption.p: Antibodies, Dilution, and Experimental Conditions Used in This Study

fn.p: Abbreviations: EDTA, ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid disodium salt dehydrate; HHV8, human herpes virus 8; EBV, Epstein–Barr virus.

sec.title: Case Description
sec.p: Light microscopic examination showed an almost complete effacement of the thyroid parenchyma by fibrous tissue accompanied by a massive plasma cell infiltration and a minimal lymphocytic component with a follicular pattern of growth. The plasma cell component was mostly represented by mature-looking elements forming large sheets and intermingled with narrow strands of fibrous tissue (Figure 1), which sometimes were confluent in the sclerotic areas (Figure 2); Congo Red stain did not disclose amyloid deposition. The IgG4+/IgG+ ratio in the plasma cells, evaluated according to the criteria of Cheuk et al,2 was near to 25%, a value inferior to the reported cutoff of significance (≥40%).

caption.p: The lesion is composed by abundant mature-looking plasma cell component, intermingled with narrow strands of fibrous tissue (hematoxylin and eosin, 20×)
Strands of fibrous tissue merge in some areas, forming sclerotic areas (hematoxylin and eosin, 10×)

sec.p: The lymphocytic component was minimal, mainly at the edge of the lesion, and was represented by few reactive germinal centers (Figure 3); the perifollicular B-cell component was almost absent and centrocyte-like/marginal cells outside secondary follicles were not identified. The polyclonal nature of the B-cell component (ie, lymphocytic and plasmacytic) was confirmed by immunohistochemistry and PCR analysis. The scanty, residual thyroid tissue showed diffuse oncocytic metaplasia (Figure 4) and fibrosis, which was negative for ALK-1 immunostaining.3 The specimen was also tested for several pathogens through different methods, including immunohistochemistry (for Chlamydia, HHV8, and EBV), in situ hybridization (for EBV), and PCR (for Chlamydia pneumoniae, C psittaci, and C trachomatis).4 All these assays gave negative results.

caption.p: Residual reactive germinal centers CD20 positives (5×)
Residual thyroid tissue with diffuse oncocytic metaplasia (hematoxylin and eosin, 200×)

sec.p: Retrospective examination of the specimen surgically removed 19 years earlier, revealed only features consistent with Hashimoto disease. As in the current specimen, the few plasma cells present showed a IgG+/IgG4 ratio below normal limits.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The characteristic lesions of PCG are well known for showing a prevalent plasma cell component, often accompanied by other inflammatory cells, including lymphocytes, neutrophils, and histiocytes, as well as a variable degree of myofibroblastic proliferation.1,5 However, none of these components is per se pathognomonic of this disorder.

The herein reported case of PCG displays a particularly prominent plasma cell component; this feature quite characteristically occurs in thyroid PCG and generates important problems in its differential diagnosis both with neoplastic and nonneoplastic (mainly dysimmune based) disorders.

Plasma cell granuloma preferentially involves the lung 5, but it has sporadically also been reported in various extrapulmonary sites.6-23 Including the present case, 19 thyroid PCG have been recorded in the English literature.11,24-39 Their salient clinical findings are summarized in Table 2. Most of these PCG have occurred in asymptomatic middle-aged women or have displayed nonspecific constitutional symptoms when associated with tracheal or esophageal compression. Almost half of the patients have shown a concomitant autoimmune disease (7 cases of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis and 1 case of diabetes mellitus); this finding supports the hypothe-sis that PCG may have a pathogenetic mechanism involving autoimmune processes. About 10% to 15% of the cases were associated with a polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia.29,38

caption.p: Main Clinical Findings of Reported Plasma Cell Granuloma in the English Literature

tr.td: Polyclonal electroforetic Ig serum component with 15% bone marrow plasmocytosis
Tiredness, fever, sore throat, painful 8-cm nodule, dysphagia
Goiter with dominant left lobe nodule
Rapid thyroid enlargement with tracheal compression
Enlarging neck mass, dysphonia, anorexia, weight loss
Goiter, feeling of narrowness in the neck
Goiter, large painless neck mass; progressively growing neck mass
IMT features ALK-1 negative, molecular exclusion EBV
Large firm irregular mass left lobe
Subioideal mass, subtotal thyroidectomy 20 y. ago

fn.p: Abbreviations: NR, not reported; IMT, inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor; HHV8, human herpes virus 8; EBV, Epstein–Barr virus; ALK-1, activin receptor-like kinase 1.

sec.p: In comparison with PCG arising in other anatomical regions, the clinical management of thyroid PCG appears distinct; in fact, since this lesion pursues a benign clinical course, surgical excision appears the treatment of choice. Satisfactory results have also been obtained with steroids or L-thyroxine.24,32 The morphologic features of thyroid PCG are summarized in Table 3. This lesion may show a diffuse or nodular growth pattern, leading to massive neck enlargement or dominant nodule in one lobe. At a variance with PCGs arising in other anatomical sites, almost every reported case of thyroid PCG (16/18) has shown the classic prominent plasma cell infiltrate within a variable degree of fibrous stroma.

caption.p: Main Pathologic Findings of Reported Plasma Cell Granuloma in the English Literature

fn.p: Abbreviations: D, diffuse; N, nodular; ++, abundant; +, low; −, absent.

sec.p: The main differential diagnosis of thyroid PCG is with lymphoproliferative diseases with plasma cell differentiation. Plasma cell myeloma is rare in the thyroid gland, either as a solitary extramedullary occurrence or as a mani-festation of systemic disease. In both instances, however, the neoplastic plasma cells will show unequivocal light chain restriction.41 Marginal zone B-cell lymphomas with mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue features may exhibit a striking plasma cell differentiation,40 able to mask the residual, minimal neoplastic lymphocyte component. In this instance, light chain restriction should be present in both (lymphocytic and plasma cell) components. The possibility of an underlying neoplastic lymphoproliferative disorder in our case was excluded by the morphology and the absence of a clonal population, as demonstrated by immunohistochemistry and molecular genetics.

Thyroid PCG also need to be distinguished from nonneoplastic diseases with pronounced plasma cell infiltrate, including infectious and auto(dys)immune disorders. Pseudotumors, especially nodal-based ones, can be the result of many infections mostly represented by treponema, herpes, EBV, borrelia, and others.42-44 The etiologic agent in these cases could be variably investigated by immunohistochemistry, molecular genetics, and serologic analysis. In our case, we did not find any association with EBV, HHV8, or Chlamydiae. The rationale for investiga-ting the latter was prompted by our previous detection of Chlamydophila psittaci DNA in an unexpected amount of lymphomas as well as reactive lymphoid tissues.4 Another peculiar reactive process characterized by prominent plasmacytosis, that is, Castleman disease, was ruled out on morphologic grounds. A recently described auto(dys)immune disease of paramount importance in the differential diagnosis with PCG is IgG4-related sclerosing disease. Although not yet described in thyroid, there is increasing evidence that this condition may involve numerous organs.45 This novel autoimmune entity is characterized by increased serum IgG4 levels and a pronounced IgG4-positive plasma cells parenchymal infiltrate, causing solitary or multiple inflammatory “pseudotumors.”2,45 The possibility of IgG4-related sclerosing disease in the present case was ruled out by the finding of normal levels of circulating IgG4 and by the immunohistochemical evaluation of IgG+/IgG4 ratio at the tissue level. This ratio was about 25%, a value below the reported cutoff of significance (≥40%) according to Cheuk et al,2 in line with the observations made by Yamamoto et al46 in the context of inflammatory pseudotumor.

Finally, at a variance with soft tissue PCGs, the myofibroblastic component in the thyroid cases is usually not prominent, although exceptions exist.30,37 Our case was negative histochemically for ALK and therefore the term “inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor” should not be used for it. Interestingly, another reported case of thyroid PCG showing a morphological overlap with inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor was also ALK-1 negative.3

In conclusion, PCG of the thyroid gland is a pseudotumoral lesion, whose pathogenesis remains unknown, with excellent prognosis after surgical removal or steroid therapy. A prompt diagnosis is essential to avoid overtreatment.
